definitions: reach or find the lowest point of something before rising again
put or attach something at the bottom or base of another object
examples: The market finally bottomed after months of decline
Oil prices bottomed out at thirty dollars per barrel
They decided to bottom the shelf with sturdy plywood
The carpenter bottomed each drawer with cedar panels

definitions: spring back quickly after hitting a surface or being compressed
move up and down repeatedly with quick energetic movements
force someone to leave a place or dismiss from employment
be returned by a bank when insufficient funds prevent payment
examples: The ball bounced high after hitting the concrete
Sound waves bounce off the canyon walls creating echoes
The excited children bounced on their beds before bedtime
She bounced into the room with infectious enthusiasm
The security guard bounced the troublemakers from the nightclub
He was bounced from three jobs in six months
Her rent check bounced because of insufficient funds
The payment bounced twice before finally clearing

definitions: move forward with leaping strides or jumps especially when running
form the boundary or limit of a particular area or region
tie or secure with rope or chains to restrict movement
be certain or destined to reach a particular place or outcome
examples: The deer bounded across the meadow toward the forest
She bounded up the stairs two at a time
Mountains bound the valley on three sides completely
The river bounds our property to the east
They bound his hands behind his back with rope
The prisoner was bound in heavy iron chains
The train is bound for Chicago this evening
She seems bound to succeed in her career

definitions: bend the head or upper body as a sign of respect or greeting
bend or cause something to bend in a curved shape
yield or submit to pressure or someone else's wishes reluctantly
play a stringed instrument using a bow to produce sound
examples: The actors bowed deeply as the audience applauded enthusiastically
He bowed politely when introduced to the ambassador
The heavy snow caused tree branches to bow dangerously
Age had bowed his shoulders over the years
She finally bowed to family pressure about the wedding
The company bowed to consumer demands for better service
The violinist bowed the strings with remarkable skill
She learned to bow properly during her cello lessons

definitions: roll a ball toward pins or a target in bowling or cricket
participate in the sport of bowling as a recreational activity
move rapidly and smoothly in a particular direction often knocking things over
examples: He bowled a perfect strike in the tenth frame
The cricket player bowled six consecutive maiden overs
They bowl together every Thursday night at the lanes
She learned to bowl when she was twelve years old
The car bowled along the empty highway at midnight
The strong wind bowled him over completely

definitions: fight an opponent with fists especially as a sport with rules
place items into a box or container for storage or transport
enclose or confine someone or something within a restricted space
examples: He boxed professionally for ten years before retiring
The two champions will box next month in Vegas
Please box these books carefully for the move tomorrow
Workers boxed thousands of products for holiday shipments
They felt boxed in by all the regulations
The narrow canyon boxed them in on three sides

definitions: refuse to buy products or services as a form of protest or pressure
refuse to participate in or cooperate with an event or organization as protest
examples: Consumers boycotted the company's products after the scandal
Several nations boycotted goods from the oppressive regime
Athletes from several countries boycotted the Olympic games
Students boycotted classes to protest the new policies

definitions: prepare oneself physically or mentally for something difficult or unpleasant coming
support or strengthen a structure with a brace or similar reinforcement device
strengthen or reinforce one's position or stance against opposition or difficulty
examples: Passengers braced themselves as the plane hit severe turbulence
She braced for the bad news about her test results
Workers braced the old wall with steel beams yesterday
They braced the roof before the hurricane arrived
The company braced its defenses against the hostile takeover
He braced his argument with solid statistical evidence

definitions: group or classify things together in the same category or range
enclose text or numbers within brackets to indicate special meaning or grouping
attach or mount something using a bracket as a supporting device
examples: The study bracketed teenagers aged thirteen to nineteen together
They bracketed these expenses under miscellaneous costs
The editor bracketed the translation in the original text
Please bracket any optional ingredients in the recipe
He bracketed the shelf firmly to the wall
They bracketed the television in the corner yesterday

definitions: talk with excessive pride about one's achievements possessions or abilities
examples: He constantly brags about his expensive new car
She bragged to everyone about her promotion
Stop bragging and show us what you can actually do
They bragged endlessly about their vacation to Europe

definitions: interlace three or more strands of hair rope or material into a pattern
decorate or trim clothing or fabric with braided cord or ribbon
examples: She braided her daughter's hair before school every morning
The sailor braided rope to make it stronger
The designer braided gold trim around the jacket collar
They braided the edges of the curtains with silk cord

definitions: transcribe or write text using the braille system of raised dots for blind readers
read text by feeling braille characters with one's fingertips
examples: The volunteer brailled dozens of textbooks for blind students
She learned to braille important documents at the library
He quickly brailles through newspapers every morning
Students braille their assignments using special equipment

definitions: hit someone hard on the head causing injury or unconsciousness
think very hard about something or rack one's brain for solutions
examples: The falling branch nearly brained him during the storm
He accidentally brained himself on the low doorway
Scientists are braining the problem from every possible angle
She brained for hours trying to remember the password

definitions: produce ideas and solutions through intensive group discussion and creative thinking
engage in intensive creative thinking to generate new ideas or solve problems individually
examples: The team brainstormed marketing strategies for three hours yesterday
Let's brainstorm some solutions to this design challenge
She brainstormed privately before presenting her ideas to management
He often brainstorms best while taking long walks

definitions: systematically change someone's beliefs or attitudes through psychological pressure and propaganda
examples: The cult leader brainwashed vulnerable followers for years
Prisoners of war were brainwashed using various psychological techniques
Advertising constantly attempts to brainwash consumers into buying products
The regime brainwashed citizens through controlled media propaganda

definitions: reduce speed or come to a stop using a brake mechanism
press or engage the brake pedal or lever to control vehicle speed
examples: The driver braked hard to avoid hitting the deer
The train braked gradually as it approached the station
She braked smoothly at every red traffic light
Always brake gently when roads are wet or icy

definitions: divide into two or more subdivisions parts or subsidiary channels
expand business operations by opening new locations or entering new markets
diverge from a main route path or course of action into different directions
examples: The river branches into several streams near the delta
The company's organization branches into five main divisions
The restaurant successfully branched into three neighboring cities
They plan to branch internationally within two years
The hiking trail branches left toward the waterfall
Her career branched in unexpected directions after graduation

definitions: mark livestock or goods with a hot iron or identifying symbol permanently
publicly label or characterize someone as having particular negative qualities unfairly
create and promote a distinctive identity for a product or company
examples: Cowboys branded cattle with the ranch's distinctive symbol
The company brands all its products with the logo
The media unfairly branded him as a troublemaker
Society often brands whistleblowers as traitors
Marketing experts helped brand the startup company successfully
They branded themselves as eco-friendly and sustainable

definitions: endure or face unpleasant or dangerous situations with courage and determination
examples: Firefighters braved the flames to rescue trapped residents
She braved criticism to speak out against injustice
Explorers braved Arctic conditions for months during the expedition
He braved his fears and gave the presentation

definitions: shout bravo as an expression of approval or praise especially after a performance
examples: The audience bravoed enthusiastically after the soprano's stunning aria
Critics bravoed the young pianist's remarkable debut performance
Fans bravoed for several minutes demanding an encore
The crowd bravoed loudly as the curtain fell

definitions: fight or quarrel in a rough noisy way especially in a public place
examples: Fans from rival teams brawled outside the stadium
The sailors brawled in the tavern after midnight
Gang members brawled in the street until police arrived
Players brawled on the field during the heated match

definitions: make the loud harsh cry characteristic of a donkey or mule
speak or laugh in a loud harsh grating voice that annoys others
examples: The donkey brayed loudly when it saw its owner
Mules brayed in the distance across the canyon
He brayed with laughter at his own terrible jokes
The drunk man brayed insults at passing strangers

definitions: endure or face an embarrassing situation with bold confidence despite criticism
examples: She brazened out the scandal refusing to resign
He brazened through the interview despite being unprepared
The politician brazened it out despite overwhelming evidence
They brazened their way past security without passes

definitions: make a gap in and break through a wall barrier or defense forcefully
fail to observe or break a law agreement or code of conduct
examples: Enemy forces breached the castle walls at dawn
Floodwaters breached the levee during the hurricane
The company breached its contract with several suppliers
He breached confidentiality by sharing sensitive information

definitions: coat food with breadcrumbs before cooking to create a crispy outer layer
examples: She breaded the chicken cutlets before frying them
The chef breaded fresh fish with seasoned panko crumbs
Always bread the vegetables just before cooking them
He breaded and fried dozens of mozzarella sticks

definitions: separate into pieces as a result of force impact or strain
interrupt the continuity flow or uniformity of something
fail to observe or comply with a law rule or agreement
become public knowledge suddenly especially of news or scandal
surpass or exceed a previous record achievement or barrier
train a horse to accept being ridden or tame a wild animal
examples: The vase broke when it fell off the shelf
Strong winds broke several tree branches last night
Let's break for lunch at noon today
The clouds broke revealing bright sunshine
Students who break school rules face suspension
He broke his promise to call her
The scandal broke just before the election
News of the merger broke this morning
She broke the world record by two seconds
Sales broke all previous monthly records
It took months to break the wild mustang
The trainer carefully broke the young colt

definitions: eat the first meal of the day typically in the morning hours
examples: We always breakfast together as a family on Sundays
The guests breakfasted on fresh fruit and pastries
She breakfasts early before heading to the office
They breakfasted at the hotel before starting their tour

definitions: face and confront a difficult situation or challenge directly with courage
reach the top or summit of a hill or wave before others
examples: The ship breasted the storm waves throughout the night
She breasted all criticism with remarkable dignity
The runner breasted the hill ahead of his competitors
Swimmers breasted the waves to reach the shore

definitions: swim using the breaststroke technique with symmetrical arm and leg movements
examples: She breaststroked across the pool in perfect form
He breaststrokes faster than he swims freestyle
Beginners often breaststroke before learning other swimming styles
The athlete breaststroked to victory in the final race

definitions: take air into the lungs and expel it as a regular process
say something very quietly barely audibly or in a whisper
allow air or moisture to pass through a material or surface
impart a quality or feeling into something making it seem alive
examples: She breathed deeply to calm her racing nerves
The patient struggled to breathe without the oxygen mask
Don't breathe a word about this to anyone
He breathed her name softly in the darkness
This fabric breathes well in hot weather conditions
Let the wine breathe before serving it
The artist breathed life into the marble sculpture
Her presence breathed new energy into the team

definitions: mate and produce offspring through biological reproduction
cause or give rise to particular conditions situations or feelings
keep animals for the purpose of producing offspring with specific qualities
examples: Rabbits breed rapidly producing several litters each year
These fish breed only in warm tropical waters
Poverty breeds crime in many urban areas
Success often breeds jealousy among colleagues
They breed champion racehorses on their Kentucky farm
She breeds pedigree dogs as a business

definitions: move in a casual confident manner with apparent ease and lack of concern
accomplish something or succeed with very little effort or difficulty
examples: She breezed into the office twenty minutes late
He breezed past security without showing identification
The team breezed through the playoffs without losing
She breezed through the exam in thirty minutes

definitions: make beer or tea by soaking steeping or fermenting ingredients
develop or form gradually especially of something unpleasant or threatening
examples: She brews her own craft beer in the garage
Let the tea brew for five minutes exactly
A storm is brewing in the Atlantic Ocean
Trouble has been brewing between the neighbors for months

definitions: offer money or favors to someone to influence their actions or decisions illegally
examples: The businessman tried to bribe the inspector with cash
Someone bribed the guard to look the other way
Politicians were bribed to vote for the controversial bill
He bribed his way out of the traffic ticket

definitions: construct or close something using bricks and mortar as building material
block access or seal an opening completely using bricks or similar materials
examples: They bricked the new garden wall last weekend
Workers bricked the fireplace with antique red bricks
The owners bricked up the old doorway permanently
They bricked in the window for better insulation

definitions: build or provide a bridge over something to allow crossing
make a connection between two things ideas periods or groups reducing differences
examples: Engineers bridged the river with a suspension structure
They bridged the gap with temporary planks
This course bridges theory and practical application perfectly
Her work bridges classical and modern artistic styles

definitions: put a bridle on a horse to control and guide it while riding
show resentment or anger especially by drawing back the head and chin
examples: She bridled the horse before the morning ride
The groom carefully bridled each horse for the lesson
He bridled at the suggestion of incompetence
She bridled when criticized about her work methods

definitions: give someone essential information or instructions about a situation or task concisely
examples: The manager briefed the team on project requirements
Lawyers briefed their clients before the trial began
The president was briefed daily on security matters
Please brief the new employees about safety procedures

definitions: organize or unite people into a group for a particular purpose or activity
examples: Volunteers were brigaded to fight the forest fires
The army brigaded several units for the operation
Workers brigaded together to demand better conditions
They brigaded local citizens to clean the beaches

definitions: make or become lighter brighter or more illuminated in appearance
make or become more cheerful optimistic or hopeful in mood or prospects
examples: Sunlight brightened the room through the clean windows
She brightened the walls with a fresh coat of paint
His face brightened when he heard the good news
The economic outlook has brightened considerably this quarter

definitions: fill something to the very top edge almost to overflowing point
be full of a particular emotion or quality to an overwhelming degree
examples: She brimmed the cup with steaming hot coffee
Rain brimmed the barrels throughout the night
Her eyes brimmed with tears of joy
He brimmed with confidence before the interview

definitions: soak or preserve food in salty water to enhance flavor or extend storage
examples: She brined the turkey overnight before roasting it
The chef brines all meats for extra flavor
They brined pickles in large wooden barrels
Fishermen brined their catch to preserve it

definitions: carry or transport someone or something to a place or person
cause something to happen occur or come into a particular state
persuade or cause someone to come to a place or join an activity
initiate or introduce something such as legal proceedings or formal charges
examples: Please bring your laptop to the meeting tomorrow
She brought flowers for her mother's birthday
The new policy brought significant changes to the company
Rain clouds are bringing storms to the region
Can you bring your sister to the party tonight?
The coach brought new players onto the team
They brought charges against the former executive
The lawyer brought the case to federal court

definitions: make or become quick active and energetic in movement or manner
examples: Business brisked up during the holiday shopping season
Cold weather brisked their walking pace considerably
Trade brisked after the new agreement was signed
The wind brisked as evening approached

definitions: react angrily or defensively showing irritation or indignation about something
of hair or fur stand up stiffly away from the skin showing aggression
examples: She bristled at his condescending remarks about women
The manager bristled when questioned about the delays
The cat's fur bristled when the dog approached
His beard bristled in the cold morning air

definitions: bring up a difficult or sensitive topic for discussion carefully
open a container or cask to use its contents for the first time
examples: She carefully broached the subject of his retirement
How should I broach this delicate matter with them?
They broached a new barrel of wine for the celebration
The captain broached the emergency supplies

definitions: transmit programs or information by radio or television to the public
tell or spread information widely to many people without discretion
examples: The station broadcasts news twenty-four hours a day
They broadcast the championship game live yesterday
Don't broadcast our personal problems to everyone
She broadcast the company secrets on social media

definitions: make or become physically wider or broader in dimension
expand or extend the range scope or variety of something
examples: They broadened the road to accommodate more traffic
The river broadens as it nears the sea
Travel really broadens your perspective on life
The university broadened its curriculum this year

definitions: attack or criticize someone or something very strongly and directly
hit or collide with something sideways with the full side exposed
examples: The senator broadsided his opponent's voting record
Critics broadsided the film for historical inaccuracies
The truck broadsided the car at the intersection
Waves broadsided the ship during the storm

definitions: arrange or negotiate a deal agreement or plan between different parties
examples: She brokered a peace agreement between the warring factions
The agent brokered several major real estate deals
Diplomats brokered a ceasefire after months of negotiation
He successfully brokered the merger between both companies
